facts.text: During and after the Second World War, Government of India instituted Grow More Food Division in Ministry of Agriculture. S. Y. Krishnaswamy placed in charge from January 2, 1947. Appellant working as Director of Fertilizers, former employee of Imperial Chemical Industries.
Fertilizers in short supply, imported from abroad. International Emergency Food Council (I.E.F.C.) set up in USA, India member. Russia not member.
Towards end of 1946, Bombay firm Messrs. Nanavati and Company offered to supply ammonium sulphate from Russia to Government of India. In 1947 and 1948, considerable quantities obtained through them.

D. N. Patel, former employee of Nanavati, joined partnership Messrs. Agri Orient Industries Limited of Bombay. Obtained contract from Government for supply of twenty thousand tons ammonium sulphate from USA in February 1950.
Patel experienced difficulty in obtaining Government orders for consignments. Appellant approached, alleged Patel paid Rs. 10,000 at Bombay as bribe to facilitate matters.

Despite payment, difficulties and delays occurred, consignments not moving fast, causing loss to Patel's firm. Patel approached Shri K. M. Munshi, Minister for Food and Agriculture, disclosed bribe payment and appellant receiving large sums as bribes.

Minister directed enquiries. Matter to Inspector-General of Special Police Establishment. Departmental committee of three senior officers held inquiry, resulted in dismissal of appellant in August 1950.
Quasi-judicial inquiry by Mr. Justice Rajadhyaksha (Bombay High Court) in 1951 on import of fertilizers. Report received January 1952.

FIR lodged April 4, 1952. Investigations led to two cases: first conspiracy involving appellant, Krishnaswamy, Nanavati proprietor etc. (not this case); second against appellant and Krishnaswamy for conspiracy to receive bribes from firms for fertilizer imports.

Special Judge found no conspiracy proved except instances in separate case. Proceeded against appellant alone under s.5(1)(a) (habitually accepting illegal gratifications) and s.5(1)(d) (habitually receiving presents abusing position).
Special Judge convicted appellant under s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act, sentence six months rigorous imprisonment.
High Court (Punjab, April 11, 1957) affirmed: evidence of PW 9 and 10 (principal witnesses on bribes) unreliable; Patel accomplice, uncorroborated. Specific bribes not proved.
High Court relied on presumption s.5(3): appellant failed to account for Rs.73,000 cash + Rs.18,000 cheques in 1947-48, disproportionate to salary.

Appellant: only son, educated in England 7 years; high paid posts 20 years ICI, Army, Govt; no children, limited expenses; saved from salary, TA; gratuity Army, PF from ICI Nov 1947; repayments loans; re-deposits withdrawals; sale old car Rs.5500 June 1948; wife's gold jewelry; borrowed Rs.20,000 Ganpat Ram pronote, deposited Aug 1948.
Bank accounts: Imperial Bank India New Delhi, Chartered Bank India Australia China Chandni Chowk; net credit over Rs.91,000.
Average salary Rs.1,100 per month; two years salary <1/3 of Rs.91,000.

legal_issues.text: Whether ingredients of s.5(3) Prevention of Corruption Act established on admitted facts.
Whether failure to prove specific instances of corruption rebuts presumption under s.5(3).
Whether appellant's statements under s.342 CrPC and written statement proved false, entitling acquittal.
Nature of burden under s.5(3): whether accused must 'satisfactorily account' for disproportionate assets beyond plausible explanation.
What constitutes 'known sources of income' for prosecution; whether proof required beyond salary.

petitioner_arguments.text: Specific instances not proved, so contrary of presumption (innocence) established.
Statements under s.342 CrPC and written statement not proved false; case not proved beyond doubt.
Plausible explanations offered for assets; like stolen property cases, doubt benefits accused.
Prosecution failed to prove known sources of income beyond salary; no evidence TA etc. not sources.
Burden on accused lighter than prosecution's; references to foreign cases.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rex v. Carr-Briant; Otto George Gfeller v. King; Hate Singh Bhagat Singh v. State of MPB; Regina v. Dunbar

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant's explanations bare, not proved; capable of easy proof but no evidence adduced.
Known sources mean those known to prosecution after investigation: salary primary for govt servant.

court_reasoning.text: S.5(3) rule of evidence raising presumption of guilt if disproportionate assets not satisfactorily accounted; departure from usual burden on prosecution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accused must prove contrary by evidence satisfying court; not mere plausible explanation.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant's bank deposits Rs.91,000 in 1947-48 disproportionate to salary (Rs.1,100/m, <1/3 total); explanations not substantiated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bare statements from dock insufficient; matters easily provable but no evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Known sources: salary for govt servant; prosecution showed via bank accounts/investigation; accused can prove others.
court_reasoning.key_observation: TA compensates expenses, not substantial income source.

court_reasoning.text: Failure of s.5(1)(a) (specific bribes) does not rebut s.5(1)(d) via s.5(3) presumption; different requirements.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presumption mandatory once conditions fulfilled; conviction valid solely on it.

court_reasoning.text: Not court of criminal appeal; will not re-examine High Court fact findings on explanations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court considered all statements, found unsubstantiated.

holdings.text: Presumption under s.5(3) arises if pecuniary resources disproportionate to known sources (salary) not satisfactorily accounted by accused.
Accused bears burden to rebut presumption by proving contrary satisfactorily; plausible not enough.
Failure to prove specific bribery under s.5(1)(a) does not preclude conviction under s.5(1)(d) via s.5(3) presumption.

precedents_cited.relevance: Burden on accused less heavy than prosecution's, but here statutory 'satisfactorily account' stricter.

precedents_cited.case_name: Otto George Gfeller v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Onus on accused for proved payment not corrupt, lighter burden.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hate Singh Bhagat Singh v. State of Madhya Bharat
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar on burden in corruption cases.
Burden on accused in possession cases.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis of charges; s.5(3) presumption for criminal misconduct if disproportionate assets not accounted.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines gratification by bribe for s.5(1)(a).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Facts in accused's knowledge; recent possession explanation.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, affirmed High Court and Special Judge's conviction under s.5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act and sentence of six months rigorous imprisonment, holding appellant failed to satisfactorily account for disproportionate bank deposits under s.5(3) presumption.

key_quotes.text: "the Legislature has advisedly used the expression 'satisfactorily account'. The emphasis must be on the word 'satisfactorily'"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines strict burden on accused to rebut presumption under s.5(3).

key_quotes.text: "his conviction therefore shall not be invalid by reason only that it is based solely on such presumption."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms conviction can rest solely on statutory presumption.

key_quotes.text: "the presumption continues to hold the field unless the contrary is proved"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Presumption persists until rebutted by cogent evidence.
